dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey, so I was reading about this incredible story, like, a real ghost airport in Spain. Have you heard of Ciudad Real?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey, so I was reading about this incredible story, like, a real ghost airport in Spain. Have you heard of Ciudad Real?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, um, I think so. Isn't that the one that was, like, supposed to be this huge thing but ended up empty?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, um, I think so. Isn't that the one that was, like, supposed to be this huge thing but ended up empty?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! So, back in the early 2000s, Europe, especially Southern Europe, was booming, right? Lots of debt, but lots of growth.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! So, back in the early two thousand seconds, Europe, especially Southern Europe, was booming, right? Lots of debt, but lots of growth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The European economy was booming, fuelled by debt in the early 2000s. Southern Europe was on a resurgent growth path which meant construction projects were easily funded to cater to this expansion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Yeah, the good old days before, you know, everything fell apart.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the good old days before, you know, everything fell apart.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. And Ciudad Real was meant to take traffic from Madrid's main airport. But get this: it was 150 miles north of Madrid. A hundred and fifty!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. And Ciudad Real was meant to take traffic from Madrid's main airport. But get this: it was one hundred fifty miles north of Madrid. A hundred and fifty!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Originally designed to take excess traffic away from Madrid Barajas airport, the airfield was located a staggering 150 miles North of the city.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: A hundred and fifty miles? Uh, that's a bit much for an "alternative," isn't it? Even for low-cost airlines.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A hundred and fifty miles? Uh, that's a bit much for an alternative, isn't it? Even for low-cost airlines.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Passengers, airlines, everyone thought it was too far. So, it opened, but it only had flights from two airlines for, like, three years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Passengers, airlines, everyone thought it was too far. So, it opened, but it only had flights from two airlines for, like, three years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the remote location of Ciudad Real seemed a little too much for passengers and airlines alike to absorb. The international airport was open for just three years and saw flights from only two airlinesRyanair and Vueling...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. And one of those was subsidized, right? I remember reading that. So, then it just sat there?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. And one of those was subsidized, right? I remember reading that. So, then it just sat there?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...and saw flights from only two airlinesRyanair and Vueling, with the latter having its flights subsidised by the government.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, literally. It fell into disrepair. They even had to paint giant yellow crosses on the runways so pilots knew it was abandoned.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, literally. It fell into disrepair. They even had to paint giant yellow crosses on the runways so pilots knew it was abandoned.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With the abandoned airport still racking up costs as it fell into disrepairincluding having to paint large yellow crosses over the crumbling runway so pilots knew the airfield was abandoned, the airport was finally put up for sale.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's wild. So, what happened next? Did they just give up on it entirely?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's wild. So, what happened next? Did they just give up on it entirely?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they tried to sell it. First, an asking price of 80 million euros, but no one bit. Then, a group of investors offered… ten *thousand* euros.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they tried to sell it. First, an asking price of eighty million euros, but no one bit. Then, a group of investors offered... ten thousand euros.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With an initial price tag of 80 million being shunned, that airport was eventually picked up in July 2015 by Tzaneen International, a group of British and Asian investors, for just 10,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Ten thousand? For an entire international airport? That's, like, less than my car!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ten thousand? For an entire international airport? That's, like, less than my car!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] I know, right? Spain's commercial court rejected that, thankfully. Eventually, it did sell for 56.2 million in 2018.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? Spain's commercial court rejected that, thankfully. Eventually, it did sell for fifty six point two million in twenty eighteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, Spains commercial court rejected the bid saying that it was too low... Three years later the airport was eventually sold for 56.2 million to Ciudad Real International Airport SL in September 2018...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, that's a bit more sensible. So, it's finally operational now? Like, with actual passengers?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, that's a bit more sensible. So, it's finally operational now? Like, with actual passengers?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, not quite. It recently had its first flight after the sale, a 747 landed… with no passengers on board. The irony!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, not quite. It recently had its first flight after the sale, a seven hundred forty seven landed... with no passengers on board. The irony!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...and the previously abandoned airport received its first flight last monthironically with no passengers on. A 747 landed at the airstrip.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, come on! So what's the plan for it now?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, come on! So what's the plan for it now?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: They're trying to rebrand it, not for passengers, though. More like tech support, maintenance, aircraft storage, because it's, um, in a dry, desert-like area.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They're trying to rebrand it, not for passengers, though. More like tech support, maintenance, aircraft storage, because it's, um, in a dry, desert-like area.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With owners now looking to rebrand the space into offering tech support, maintenance and flight training... which includes aircraft storage in the dry desert-like environment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, basically, a giant airplane parking lot and repair shop?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, basically, a giant airplane parking lot and repair shop?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. And the kicker? Madrid might be getting a *new* second airport, only 20 miles away. So, Ciudad Real's passenger dreams are still, like, way up in the air.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. And the kicker? Madrid might be getting a new second airport, only twenty miles away. So, Ciudad Real's passenger dreams are still, like, way up in the air.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: What a saga. It just keeps getting more complicated.
